Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Situation2: They greet a few customers politely while scanning items at a quiet store.
Story:
I stood behind the register, scanning groceries and offering polite smiles to the handful of customers trickling in. My mentor’s words echoed in my mind: “Try to finish the code sample before our next meeting.” Three days. That’s all I had. I could feel the weight of the assignment pressing on me, the expectation to impress and not let my mentor down. But here, as a cashier, I was expected to be present, friendly, and attentive to every customer. 

A woman approached, her cart full. I greeted her, but my mind drifted to the unfinished lines of code waiting for me at home. Each beep of the scanner was a reminder of the time slipping away. I wanted to focus on the customer, to be the helpful cashier my manager praised, but anxiety gnawed at me. What if I couldn’t finish the assignment? What if my mentor thought I wasn’t committed? 

I forced another smile, feeling the tension between wanting to be a good mentee and a good cashier. The demands pulled me in opposite directions, and I could feel myself caught in the middle, unsure which role to prioritize as the next customer stepped forward.
